natural problem: What is the greatest common factor of all two-digit palindromes?  (Note: A palindrome is a number that reads the same forwards as backwards.)
natural solution: Palindromes are numbers whose digits read from left to right and from right to left result in the same number. All two-digit palindromes (11, 22,...99) can be factored into 11 and a number between 1 and 9.
The only factor that all of them share is $\boxed{11}$, so that is our answer.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n > 9"
and h1 : "n < 100"
and h2 : "palindrome n"
shows  "greatest_common_factor n 11 = 11"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the greatest common factor of all two-digit palindromes?  (Note: A palindrome is a number that reads the same forwards as backwards.) The final Answer is 11
 ### Proof
 Palindromes are numbers whose digits read from left to right and from right to left result in the same number. All two-digit palindromes (11, 22,...99) can be factored into 11 and a number between 1 and 9.
 The only factor that all of them share is $\boxed{11}$, so that is our answer.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n > 9"
and h1 : "n < 100"
and h2 : "palindrome n"
shows  "greatest_common_factor n 11 = 11"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: For a natural number $n$ which is a palindrome and greater than 9 but less than 100, prove that the greatest common factor of $n$ and 11 is 11.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b :: nat
assumes h0 : "\<forall> a b. (a \<ge> 1 \<and> a \<le> 9) \<and> (b \<ge> 0 \<and> b \<le> 9) \<longrightarrow> (a*10 + b = b*10 + a)"
shows  "Gcd {ab. (\<exists> a b. (a \<ge> 1 \<and> a \<le> 9) \<and> (b \<ge> 0 \<and> b \<le> 9) \<and> (ab = a*10 + b))} = 11"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the greatest common factor of all two-digit palindromes?  (Note: A palindrome is a number that reads the same forwards as backwards.) The final Answer is 11
 ### Proof
 Palindromes are numbers whose digits read from left to right and from right to left result in the same number. All two-digit palindromes (11, 22,...99) can be factored into 11 and a number between 1 and 9.
 The only factor that all of them share is $\boxed{11}$, so that is our answer.
 *)

theorem
fixes a b :: nat
assumes h0 : "\<forall> a b. (a \<ge> 1 \<and> a \<le> 9) \<and> (b \<ge> 0 \<and> b \<le> 9) \<longrightarrow> (a*10 + b = b*10 + a)"
shows  "Gcd {ab. (\<exists> a b. (a \<ge> 1 \<and> a \<le> 9) \<and> (b \<ge> 0 \<and> b \<le> 9) \<and> (ab = a*10 + b))} = 11"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Find the greatest common divisor of all two-digit numbers that remain the same when their digits are reversed. The final answer is 11.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b :: int
assumes h0 : "a \<ge> 10"
and h1 : "a \<le> 99"
and h2 : "b \<ge> 10"
and h3 : "b \<le> 99"
and h4 : "palindrome a"
and h5 : "palindrome b"
shows  "greatest_common_factor a b = 11"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the greatest common factor of all two-digit palindromes?  (Note: A palindrome is a number that reads the same forwards as backwards.) The final Answer is 11
 ### Proof
 Palindromes are numbers whose digits read from left to right and from right to left result in the same number. All two-digit palindromes (11, 22,...99) can be factored into 11 and a number between 1 and 9.
 The only factor that all of them share is $\boxed{11}$, so that is our answer.
 *)

theorem
fixes a b :: int
assumes h0 : "a \<ge> 10"
and h1 : "a \<le> 99"
and h2 : "b \<ge> 10"
and h3 : "b \<le> 99"
and h4 : "palindrome a"
and h5 : "palindrome b"
shows  "greatest_common_factor a b = 11"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Find the greatest common factor of two 2-digit palindromic numbers $a$ and $b$ (a palindromic number is a number that remains the same when its digits are reversed). The final answer is $11$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: int and palindrome :: "int \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. palindrome n = (n > 9 \<and> n < 100 \<and> n div 10 = n mod 10)"
shows  "Gcd {n. palindrome n} = 11"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the greatest common factor of all two-digit palindromes?  (Note: A palindrome is a number that reads the same forwards as backwards.) The final Answer is 11
 ### Proof
 Palindromes are numbers whose digits read from left to right and from right to left result in the same number. All two-digit palindromes (11, 22,...99) can be factored into 11 and a number between 1 and 9.
 The only factor that all of them share is $\boxed{11}$, so that is our answer.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: int and palindrome :: "int \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. palindrome n = (n > 9 \<and> n < 100 \<and> n div 10 = n mod 10)"
shows  "Gcd {n. palindrome n} = 11"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Find the greatest common divisor of all two-digit palindromic numbers. The final answer is 11.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: int
assumes h0 : "n \<ge> 10"
and h1 : "n \<le> 99"
and h2 : "n = rev n"
shows  "gcd n 11 = 11"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the greatest common factor of all two-digit palindromes?  (Note: A palindrome is a number that reads the same forwards as backwards.) The final Answer is 11
 ### Proof
 Palindromes are numbers whose digits read from left to right and from right to left result in the same number. All two-digit palindromes (11, 22,...99) can be factored into 11 and a number between 1 and 9.
 The only factor that all of them share is $\boxed{11}$, so that is our answer.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: int
assumes h0 : "n \<ge> 10"
and h1 : "n \<le> 99"
and h2 : "n = rev n"
shows  "gcd n 11 = 11"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: If $n$ is a two-digit integer such that the reverse of $n$ is equal to $n$ itself, what is the greatest common divisor of $n$ and $11$? The final answer is $11$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b :: int and f :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> a b. a \<ge> 1 \<and> a \<le> 9 \<and> b \<ge> 0 \<and> b \<le> 9 \<longrightarrow> f (10*a + b) = 10*b + a"
and h1 : "\<forall> a b. a \<ge> 1 \<and> a \<le> 9 \<and> b \<ge> 0 \<and> b \<le> 9 \<longrightarrow> 11 dvd (10*a + b)"
shows  "f (10*a + b) = 11"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the greatest common factor of all two-digit palindromes?  (Note: A palindrome is a number that reads the same forwards as backwards.) The final Answer is 11
 ### Proof
 Palindromes are numbers whose digits read from left to right and from right to left result in the same number. All two-digit palindromes (11, 22,...99) can be factored into 11 and a number between 1 and 9.
 The only factor that all of them share is $\boxed{11}$, so that is our answer.
 *)

theorem
fixes a b :: int and f :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> a b. a \<ge> 1 \<and> a \<le> 9 \<and> b \<ge> 0 \<and> b \<le> 9 \<longrightarrow> f (10*a + b) = 10*b + a"
and h1 : "\<forall> a b. a \<ge> 1 \<and> a \<le> 9 \<and> b \<ge> 0 \<and> b \<le> 9 \<longrightarrow> 11 dvd (10*a + b)"
shows  "f (10*a + b) = 11"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Given a function $f$ such that for all integer values $a$ and $b$ satisfying $1 \leq a \leq 9$ and $0 \leq b \leq 9$, $f(10a + b) = 10b + a$. Also, for the same range of $a$ and $b$, $10a + b$ is divisible by $11$. Find the value of $f(10a + b)$. The final answer is $11$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b :: nat
assumes h0 : "a mod 10 = a div 10 \<and> a \<ge> 10 \<and> a < 100"
and h1 : "b \<ge> 10 \<and> b < 100"
and h2 : "\<forall>c. (c dvd a \<and> c dvd b) \<longrightarrow> c dvd (gcd a b)"
shows  "gcd a b = 11"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the greatest common factor of all two-digit palindromes?  (Note: A palindrome is a number that reads the same forwards as backwards.) The final Answer is 11
 ### Proof
 Palindromes are numbers whose digits read from left to right and from right to left result in the same number. All two-digit palindromes (11, 22,...99) can be factored into 11 and a number between 1 and 9.
 The only factor that all of them share is $\boxed{11}$, so that is our answer.
 *)

theorem
fixes a b :: nat
assumes h0 : "a mod 10 = a div 10 \<and> a \<ge> 10 \<and> a < 100"
and h1 : "b \<ge> 10 \<and> b < 100"
and h2 : "\<forall>c. (c dvd a \<and> c dvd b) \<longrightarrow> c dvd (gcd a b)"
shows  "gcd a b = 11"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Given two natural numbers $a$ and $b$ both greater than or equal to 10 but less than 100. If $a$ is such that when divided by 10, the remainder is equal to the quotient, determine the greatest common divisor (gcd) of $a$ and $b$. The gcd of $a$ and $b$ is 11.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: int
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. 10 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 99 \<longrightarrow> n mod 11 = 0"
shows  "gcd 11 n = 11"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the greatest common factor of all two-digit palindromes?  (Note: A palindrome is a number that reads the same forwards as backwards.) The final Answer is 11
 ### Proof
 Palindromes are numbers whose digits read from left to right and from right to left result in the same number. All two-digit palindromes (11, 22,...99) can be factored into 11 and a number between 1 and 9.
 The only factor that all of them share is $\boxed{11}$, so that is our answer.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: int
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. 10 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 99 \<longrightarrow> n mod 11 = 0"
shows  "gcd 11 n = 11"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: "If an integer $n$ between 10 and 99 inclusive is divisible by 11, what is the greatest common divisor of 11 and $n$?" The final answer is 11.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes g :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>a b. g a b = (GREATEST x. x dvd a \<and> x dvd b)"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. 10 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 99 \<longrightarrow> g n (n div 10 + 10 * (n mod 10)) = 11"
shows  "11 = (GREATEST x. \<forall>n. 10 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 99 \<longrightarrow> x dvd n div 10 + 10 * (n mod 10))"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the greatest common factor of all two-digit palindromes?  (Note: A palindrome is a number that reads the same forwards as backwards.) The final Answer is 11
 ### Proof
 Palindromes are numbers whose digits read from left to right and from right to left result in the same number. All two-digit palindromes (11, 22,...99) can be factored into 11 and a number between 1 and 9.
 The only factor that all of them share is $\boxed{11}$, so that is our answer.
 *)

theorem
fixes g :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>a b. g a b = (GREATEST x. x dvd a \<and> x dvd b)"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. 10 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 99 \<longrightarrow> g n (n div 10 + 10 * (n mod 10)) = 11"
shows  "11 = (GREATEST x. \<forall>n. 10 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 99 \<longrightarrow> x dvd n div 10 + 10 * (n mod 10))"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Given a function $g(a, b)$ that returns the greatest common divisor of $a$ and $b$, if for all two-digit numbers $n$, $g(n, n/10 + 10*(n \mod 10)) = 11$, prove that $11$ is the greatest number that can divide $n/10 + 10*(n \mod 10)$ for all two-digit numbers $n$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes gcf :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
and palindrome :: "nat \<Rightarrow> bool"
and n :: nat
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. palindrome n = (n = rev n)"
and h1 : "n \<ge> 10"
and h2 : "n \<le> 99"
and h3 : "palindrome n"
shows  "gcf n 11 = 11"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the greatest common factor of all two-digit palindromes?  (Note: A palindrome is a number that reads the same forwards as backwards.) The final Answer is 11
 ### Proof
 Palindromes are numbers whose digits read from left to right and from right to left result in the same number. All two-digit palindromes (11, 22,...99) can be factored into 11 and a number between 1 and 9.
 The only factor that all of them share is $\boxed{11}$, so that is our answer.
 *)

theorem
fixes gcf :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
and palindrome :: "nat \<Rightarrow> bool"
and n :: nat
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. palindrome n = (n = rev n)"
and h1 : "n \<ge> 10"
and h2 : "n \<le> 99"
and h3 : "palindrome n"
shows  "gcf n 11 = 11"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: If $n$ is a two-digit palindrome, does the greatest common factor of $n$ and $11$ equal $11$?
